parts.text: Hello my name is Glen Loxton and I am going to have a
conversation with Rosemarie ROMANO For visible
glide and World History Project at the New York Public Library. It
is Monday afternoon February twenty third two thousand and
fifteen and this is being recorded at Helen Keller's services for the
Blind in Brooklyn New York. So Rosemarie thank you very
much for agreeing to be interviewed we're really looking forward to your story.
Maybe you'd like to start by telling me a little bit about where you come from.
Thank you for having me Lynn. I was born in Brooklyn.
My parents realize pretty quickly that I was visually
impaired. I was the first of three children
. My parents were.
Adamant about finding. Whatever the
best doctor said to try to do something about my. Vision
disability. And I would have
gone to any place to the moon if they thought they could find a doctor that could
help me. I lived a pretty regular
or normal. Childhood with a family and soon
after I had had a sister and then a brother
and I pretty much was. Involved with the
family or part of the family.
I was included in whatever activities the family was involved in no matter
what it was. At about the age of.
Six I was in rolled at the New York Institute for the Blind in the
Bronx. Where
I. Went to school from
kindergarten through high school.
The school. Was great in terms of
education. We learned a lot educationally we did
very well. I don't think we suffered at all educationally because they had every
facility to help us work to our maximum level.
What I was not particularly happy about was that I
had to go to school on either Sunday night or Monday morning and come
home on Friday which took me away from my family.
This I found very trying because we were and
are a pretty tight family and although. I
admit we are in different types of people and different people and learn to try
to live with others in a
cooperative manner. I still very much miss being
with my family I don't think I ever got over that even through high school I mean I
think I was better about it but I never really
was totally happy with the situation as I said the
education was great. We
not only were educated in terms of book learning and things
like that but we did learn to try to get along with others and try to cope
with other's people's mannerisms disabilities
wants and wants etc.
We did things like physical activity you know like gym and physical activity
. We were fortunate enough to be taking
it on field trips where I really feel we
learned a great deal again about. Being together about
other people about other things other ways of life
etc. One of the biggest
things that I really got from the Institute was learning to deal with other
people and their backgrounds etc
For instance we all celebrated. Different
holidays not only Christmas we celebrate it with the Jewish Students also the
holidays we went to their Seders on and there
was religious instruction for the various groups at the institute
which I found. Very interesting and
educational. Really. Time passed and
graduation came.
I was home for a while and then got involved here at
Helen Keller. Except that at that time it was called the Industrial Home for the blind
and entered into the rehab
program which was in Jamaica at the time it was across the street from the Long Island
Railroad.
And it was an easy bus trip. Now traveling has always been an issue with me
because I come from a family where Daddy took you everyplace.
So I never liked traveling alone. I don't like excess or ride either but it's
better than traveling alone. But. In
those days though you needed to prove that you could travel along because they
would not help you get a job unless you could do that
In those days. Also now it was time to be sponsored by the state commission which was
cool. OK We had beat service at the time and
we had to be evaluated in terms of our
personal. Care and also our skills for
going to work. While here at my age
. Helen Keller.
I was asked if I would like to try it out on the
switchboard. And in those days switch boards were run
by people who pushed and pulled cords all the time so I was truly in the middle
of everything because everything went to the switchboard interoffice
outside coming in and all the disconnects all the comings and goings of
various staff members taking messages etc Could you explain that
to people who have grown up on the digital age when
push and pull cord to me but what did you do
when you did that
. OK We're the switchboard was almost like a desk.
If it was like two panels in front of you straight up and you know
in front of you straight up and down the bottom row
of. These panels were for the
Plugs. He would go into these jacks
and they were for the calls coming in or going out. I was with the
outside lines above that.
There were rows of extensions which were would
be. For the person
who was inside picking up the phone wanting to get the switchboard. Be it
for an outside line an interoffice school etc You
had plugs which I guess you think of a
long cord in a box that you pulled out and you had to plug these
. Cords it to be it. Whatever the call
was be it extension or be it incoming or outgoing call and use
the other call to complete the call all the other chord to complete the call. OK thank
you thank you. Yeah.
So you want to switch point. Yeah but I had had experience at the switchboard in school
but in school they had like a panels to the side and it was in braille
so you knew where to plug in. BI What's the Braille code taught you but that was very
expensive and very inefficient. The switchboard at Helen
H.P. Helen Keller.
Was. Set up with a sound
Like a like a week and you
ran like a light Crow. Laws
which look like a pencil along the the strip where
the coal was lit up and then you knew by when
it hit the row on which the extent it was lit. You would know to probe
until you got a second squeak or light up etc and that's
how you knew. Eventually they expanded on that and we had three different
sounds we had one for incoming calls one for calls within the building and one
for Disconnect. So it made it less probing and therefore.
The operation was more it was quicker. And as
it turned out we had people from the telephone company come at a
time. And I could keep up with the sighted operator.
Wonderful OK. They
decided they liked me and they hired me I will never
forget the supervisor saying he was embarrassed. To
offer me the salary they were offering me but he what he did know was I would have done it for
nothing. So it was fine. Since
then equipment has been expanded and has been
improved and a visually impaired
person doesn't have any problem answering a switchboard or any or.
A phone with extensions or multiple lines
or whatever. Pretty much you don't almost even don't have to use a light probe
so that was very good we did a lot with that. We did a lot of
training for people to be. Placed which we were good we did well
we got a grant from. The Department of
Health Education and Welfare. So it was a government grant and we train people
under that Grant went to West Point because of that. Went to
another various veterans' hospitals various places of
business. And
you know it worked out pretty well with visually impaired people were able to do this and
it worked out very well. Remember we placed a lady. Who
There were four thousand extensions. Oh my oh my. And she could
do it. She could do it because of course she memorized the ones that were
most prevalent.
And we were held a Rolodex full of all the
. Individuals and their extensions. That
was.
Truly teamwork. Anybody who knew Braille and helped
out on on you know creating that list for her that we made it
of a Rolodex file and she was very
successful she worked went to work for a brokerage house and did very well. That
was one of the things we did. As as I said
as phone and switchboards improves we improved but we always
have that as a. Or
viable accommodation for someone who wish to be
. Hired in an office setting. Now
. One has to do more than answer the phone but
so therefore you know this is a much additional training that has to be done
than was done in those days
from now we moved to. New Hyde Park
. We continue the training.
And.
Again we continue training to take people from upstate even that came
down under the grant. From the air. Now
technology was coming in so once we got to the Hempstead office which is a permanent
borders on Long Island these days. We started
technology training. Believe it or
not we started originally what was called was an I.B.M. talking typewriter
was not the computer that we know today.
And do you want to tell us a little something about it because I may not know exactly what
that is because it was pretty fabulous I mean we thought it was the end of the earth was great
because it talked what you typed. So you know prior to
this use we used a regular typewriter with a touch type system
. And again people were placed at jobs doing dictation
. From a dictaphone. But now
we're talking typewriter that it tells you when you made a mistake. Yes And
on that you could even save a file. Which was like the predecessor to what we
know now is the computers.
From where we got to a whale
device again which saved me what you imported and
then you could print it if necessary. Preprinted. We could print it
also but it had to be hooked up to the printer.
From there we started with the technology. Here again
in Hempstead. We got a grant for equipment and we got
a benefactor. Name was
Leonardo.
Trying to go with Leonardo again OK.
So.
Again. We help set up the unit to treat people with that's a commission
for the contract from the commission. We then had to abide by the contract to
kill the guy saying it was Leonardo Del Vecchio. And later on
his son donated the money to upgrade the equipment that's why I want to get it they don't
close it.
And his son and daughter in law became benefactors and Helen Keller they even were on the
board etc But getting back to the technology
center we were really one of the early people agencies
to set up a program. Again. I was very much involved with setting that
program up. And training individuals again either to go to work
or go to school or be able to go to you know attend college. Many of
those. Students were sponsored by The New York
state commission for the blind. Who are instrumental
in helping us to get this oil off the ground. And during
all of that time I became married. I had a child. I moved from
Brooklyn to Queens. I had a pretty active
social life. My husband was visually impaired also. He
became the director of the Hempstead office. We
had a pretty terrific social life interacting with.
People with a vision and without vision I mean that never seem to be a problem do
we. I take care of. I
have always taken care of the house. Love always
been organized in terms of not only the house but clothing
and equipment etc Same way with my work situation
. I'm reasonably organized in terms of getting it done
writing the reports getting the reports out etc. So I feel
. That I'm a very fortunately. I didn't
include the fact that I have a daughter. Who has now twins
. Again I feel
fortunate that I've had such a good life. Due to the fact that I've
been fortunate enough to come from a good basic family and have met
wonderful people through my career.
In my life and I hope to continue to do this so that you know and
they tell me something you've you've had some travels and you have some outside
interests you would tend to see if you're another sitting
. Short You know so this will be interesting to hear about them.
Again it Helen Keller. A lady
called up looking for service for a young lady from Bermuda
. At that time there weren't any services for visually impaired individuals in
Bermuda. And
The director my husband Frank Romano told her. What's the big deal. Bring her in
. And this lady was with us for
about a month. We taught her what. Ever we could in terms
of dealing with a visual impairment and how to be organized etc She
was extremely bright lady. Subsequent to that we had a number of people come in
from Bermuda for the same kind of training.
And through that I met the lady that. Brought brought this
individual to us in the first place and we became you know stop to
go to lunch.
Next if we don't know maybe the husbands should meet each other and through her
I was able to really do a lot of things that I probably would never have gotten
to do. Firstly he liked each other she didn't care to shop for her but as long as I was shopping and spending
money it was fight. She didn't care where we went. We could go to the moon. All I had to say was
let's we went so we did a lot of shopping. We did.
A great deal of the.
Sierra and movies and
Museums and things like that and this lady is still
alive and she was fabulous in turnout in terms of describing things
. She was really so good at that that it really made the
situation alive and really make you feel like you know you were
part of wherever it was that we were
With her and her husband. We went to California we went to Italy
. We went upstate a couple of times to like long
weekends we went to Florida.
Washington. Even went to the White House with
what they had won something from you know like a raffle and it was to go to
the White House and we did that we went to Congress. Oh my.
So it was a lucky thing for a wonderful thing to me that
you know circumstances enabled me to meet this lady and.
And I interact with her through all these various educational and social things
. Now through that. She brought a number
of people from Bermuda to us for training. Another lady went to
. Went to college and became a psychiatrist.
The first lady became a teacher and has now retired. Oh my
. We went to Bermuda to come to
think of it. We went to Bermuda on a Lions you know
vacation in you know meeting etc thing
and. You know again
. It was an experience it was a great experience.
You know we left because as soon as. The word Let's came up we did
it. Unfortunately this
lady is now you know.
Both too old to do that kind of running around and more dead than we once
did but it was. Really fortunate
for us that we were able to meet this lady and it was really good because
she came looking for service for the for the lady from me so you know God has
strange ways of doing so is that what you want.
Yes and also on tell us a little something about you or
volunteer work.
The training you did at the Brooklyn Museum. All
. Through Helen Keller.
We were contacted by the Brooklyn Museum. Now. We are both
located in downtown Brooklyn. Helen Keller is at.
Fifty seven Willoughby St in the Brooklyn Museum I think it's two hundred Washington haven't you.
And they wanted the Brooklyn Museum the lady at the Brooklyn Museum. I
wanted to create what they called a touch towards it and make
it comfortable for visually impaired individuals to visit the museum
and. You know participate in their activities so we and Helen
Keller myself and three or four other staff went to the Brooklyn
Museum a couple of times to try to help them and they are counting on to us they still
are having to us for visually impaired I don't know well what else but
I get an email. Maybe once a month that there's a particular
. Exhibit. If I'm interested at the Brooklyn
Museum Usually it is that they are evening and I can go but it's very nice
But this has been very very interesting now in years to come once somebody listens
to us. Do you have words of wisdom
or something in particular a few cogent comment in
particular that you would like people to remember about
your story and what you've told us today.
OK my first thing is that.
You'd have to try to. Make it help people to understand
. That. Visual Impairment is visual impairment but you
are a person first. You happen to be a person who cannot see with your
eyes. You can't see in other ways you can be interested in other ways. You're
normal in other ways and you have all the likes dislikes bad habits good habits
annoyances that anybody else would have so you are a person
first. Then visually impaired and
I really and truly feel that it is important to help
people who are not used to dealing with visual impairment
to be comfortable and not make an issue over how they should help you or
what they can do for you you can show them or tell them in a nice way how best
. To help them you don't want to make people uncomfortable you want.
The most important thing is to have people feel comfortable in being with you.
And I always tell people they can ask me whatever they want. It's up to me to
handle it and I think that that's something that most
visually impaired individuals should really try to live by
. That sounds like very good advice. There's just one other area of
technology that people might be interested in because you started off
talking about well years back with the switchboard
and you mentioned technology was coming to get just some racial a little bit
what the computer does and how you work with that computer
now.
I'm sorry I should have or I don't know this is a good time to do it
The computers are regular computers that anyone has.
The adaptive equipment which means large print. Or speech or Braille
is just an extra program which is loaded into the computer.
So for instance for me I have a speech program called
JAWS J W S which is speech
X. is speech.
Which you can say you know which is most comfortable for you. I usually
do have it separated by word or by letter because I want to be able to
listen to it back but it depends on your needs. But Joyce's job
access with speech and that's really what it's supposed to be supposed to be
. Allow you access to the computer. We pretty
much can do everything that a sighted person can do with the
exception of. The graphics or the
you know pictures.
There are programs in large print which enlarged
the whatever is on the screen and I guess if
someone has enough vision they would be able to do more graphic type
stuff than say I could do. In
fact right now we have two students as like in terms.
Who are really doing great things with a computer. With a large
print and all kinds of visual things pictures and
graphics and videos and creating videos and things like
that which would not have been done in years gone by
on. The computers. Again allow
us to work
. Allow us to go to school. Allow us to
e-mail us to use the Internet
and gives us almost almost the same access as a sighted
person. I find this very interesting and
rewarding. I mean I can imagine that we have a didn't have a computer to rely on
That's pretty much it and it's opened up a new world.
Full of wonderful. Thank you very much for
sharing your story with us. For this oral history
project.
